People Power President
Likes civilizations that keep their people happy. Dislikes civilizations with unhappy citizens and also those with other governments.
(Your citizens are happy.)
Corazon Aquino is pleased that your people are happy and thriving.
(Your citizens are unhappy.)
Corazon Aquino sees that your people are unhappy under your rule.
(You follow a different government.)
Corazon Aquino believes you to be a tyrant.

Greetings, Corazon Aquino: Mother of Asian Democracy. From a plain housewife to the first female President of the Philippines, you have made great strides in your struggle against tryanny. Now, let your people reap the riches of the Philippines and fling open the doors to visitors, that they may sample a taste of these Fiesta Islands. The people look to you to guide them, for you have shown them the power that they possess. You have brought peaceful revolution to the Philippines - what will you do now?
Ina ng Demokrasya

President of the Philippines

Eurydice I was the wife of King Amyntas III. She is believed to have been of Lyncestian ancestry, although writers such as Plutarch hold that she was Illyrian. Eurydice, with Amynatas, had three sons - Alexander II, Perdiccas III, and Philip II - all of whom would become King of Macedon. She was also the grandmother of Alexander the Great.

Eurydice was born between 410 and 404 BCE to a noble named Sirras. She married Amyntas in her 20s, probably as a diplomatic attempt to secure peace between Macedon and her people. Amyntas's rule was tumultous; Greek Chalcidians took a large portion of the kingdom, including Pella, until Sparta intervened. Nevertheless, Eurydice was able to supplant Amyntas's primary wife Gygaea to assume the title of Queen. Amyntas III died c. 370 BCE and the kingdom soon began to experience grave troubles. Eurydice's first son, Alexander II took the throne but was killed 2 years later by Ptolemy of Aloros; an agreement worked out by Theban statesman Pelopidas preserved some Macedonian sovereignty, as Ptolemy became regent for Eurydice's two other sons. To protect them, Eurydice married Ptolemy. During Ptolemy's regency for Perdiccas, a noble named Pausanias attempted to usurp the throne. Eurydice asked for help from the Athenian general Iphicrates, who succeeded in driving out Pausanias. Eurydice's bold action likely saved the kingdom and was an extraordinary act for a woman at this time. For this and other reasons, Eurydice's reign is often believed to have marked a turning point in the role of women in Macedon.

Eurydice was very much involved in the affairs of state and the culture of Macedon. She is believed to have funded the construction of a temple dedicated to Eucleia, the female spirit of glory, at Vergina. She is also believed to have learned to read and write late in her life - a talent she believed was a gift of the Muses. The date of her death is unknown, but it is believed to have been between 365 and 359 BCE, meaning that she probably died before seeing her youngest son, Philip II, assume the throne. Philip and his descendants did not forget about Eurydice, however; her portrait-statue was included as part of the Philippeion at Olympia, built to commemorate Philip's victory at the Battle of Chaeronea in 338 BCE. Though little is solidly known about the life of Eurydice, her valor and bravery outlived her. Aeschines considered her to be a loyal defender of her sons, and Plutarch wrote that she was a model to emulate when educating children.

Eurydice's greatest strengths lie in her relationships with her allies. If you can isolate her diplomatically, her advantages will crumble. Be wary, however, for though she may seem to be more oriented towards defense, Macedonian troops can still pack quite the punch!

As Eurydice, your greatest advantage is unlocked midway through civics tree at Civil Service, which unlocks alliances; unlocking this civic should be a priority for you. Before reaching the medieval era, try to cultivate friendships with nearby civs that you can then elevate into alliances. Also feel free to try and pursue a religion in the early game; with the bonus science from Holy Site buildings, focusing on early religion won't be as punishing for you as it might be for other leaders.
Kumusta - I am Corazon Aquino, President of the Philippines. What brings you here to our island country?
Would you care to visit one of the Fiesta Islands' many splendors?
How delightful - I look foward to visiting your country.
Let us exchange information about our capitals - to work together requires we know where the other one is, no?
Hello again.
I am most grateful for your generosity.
I'm afraid I must turn your gifts away at this time.
Please accept these tokens of my esteem: fresh coconuts, a stylish Barong Tagalog, and samples of some of my favorite Original Pilipino music!
A country must be open if it is to be free - I accept.
Ha! So that you can make yourself at home at Subic Bay? I swear that you shall not enter this country.
The path to peace and democracy is a global one - may we enter your lands in pursuit of that goal?
Of course! We, the Filipinos, thank you for what you do.
Impossible.
Do you consider yourself a friend of freedom - Would you proclaim to be a friend of the Philippines?
Outstanding.
A disappointing decision.
Will you stand with me? The People Power Revolution is not something for only the Philippines; others around the world must know the sweet taste of freedom.
You understand that freedom is essential, and your people relish their liberties.
You crush your people under the weight of your tyranny. Can't you see the harm you are doing?
The sovereignty of the Philippines must be respected. Remove your troops at once.
A fair exchange for both our nations - I accept.
I cannot accept this.
Your disregard for the rights of your citizens has become too much for me to bear. The Philippines hereby denounces your crimes to the world.
You crush the spirit of freedom; you seek to break it by indignities and terror. I cannot abide by that (Denounces You).
You may think me but a humble housewife, but I will fight for my country until the very end. I shall not submit.
You have gone too far - the spirit of democracy that inheres in our race and animates my actions can not be allowed to die.
I agree - now is the time for peace.
No, the score is not yet settled.
I come to you to ask for a cessation of hostilities. What do you say?
And so it seems I must lay to rest this restless dream of Philippine freedom.
And so it seems I must lay to rest this restless dream of Philippine freedom.
